This morning, 78 district staff members attended a training either in person or via Zoom headed by Middle School Teacher, Ryan Dunmire-Kuftic on “Making Google Classroom Work for You”. Through this session, staff learned strategies to make Google Classroom more effective and efficient. There was not only a great turn out but also various applications were discussed! “The staff was eager and excited to learn! They were very engaged with what I was demonstrating and asked some really great questions! Overall, I’d say it was a great success and I’ve received really good feedback,” said Dunmire-Kuftic.

This Professional Development Session was voluntary and one of a few that the district is offering for staff to get better prepared for the upcoming year using our own staff members. The next session will be held on August 4th by Special Education Teachers, Erin Noblet and Jillian Braszo entitled “Suite in your classroom to better support special education students".

March 23 at 2:27 PM · South Park, PA ·

Working from home today and did a FaceTime interview with a local teacher who is sewing masks for nurses.

She knows these aren’t N-95 level protection but is hopeful they can provide an extra layer of protection for the medical providers who only have one mask — or no masks at all.

She also formed a Facebook group for anyone wanting to learn how to sew these 4-layer, pleated 100% cotton masks or donate supplies.

Masks for Healthcare Providers Facebook Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/661053608043019/?ref=share

I want to continue sharing these positive stories, so please send them my way. ❤️

While there, 41 members were able to explore the museum and learn about the life and works of one of Pittsburgh’s most iconic artists. Students had the opportunity to participate in a Pop Portrait Workshop where they examined the many ways in which Andy Warhol created portraits throughout his career, from painting and Polaroids, to silkscreening and selfies. They were then able to create their own silkscreen print of a contemporary Pop culture icon in the style of Warhol. Students were able to attend this field trip free of charge through a generous scholarship supported by the Grable Foundation and Dollar Bank.

Mal Goode

Mal Goode was the first African American network correspondents. Goode was born in White Plains, Virginia, educated in the public school system of Homestead, Pennsylvania, and graduated from the University of Pittsburgh in 1931. In 1962 he became the first Black network news correspondent for ABC television network as a United Nations (UN) reporter. He allegedly received this position after baseball player Jackie Robinson, who was the first Black player in the major leagues, complained to ABC executives about the lack of Black reporters. Goode's first assignment was covering the Cuban Missile Crisis; he distinguished himself with incisive TV and radio reports during the long hours of debate at the UN.

A member of the Ironmen pitching rotation since his freshman season, Nick made an immediate impact when he threw a no-hitter in his first career appearance. Since then, he has amassed 108 career strikeouts while allowing only 75 total hits. His success as a pitcher tabbed him the starter for many playoff games during his career. This past season, Nick was the starting pitcher for the Ironmen in the WPIAL Class 3A Championship game and helped the Ironmen capture their second WPIAL championship in the past five years. Before heading off to be part of the Gannon pitching staff, Nick will once again be looked upon to be a leader for the Ironmen during their 2020 campaign.
"We wish Nick well at Gannon University. He will be a wonderful addition to their program. Congratulations to the Harhai family, and best wishes to Nick in his future with the Golden Knights,” said Steel Valley Athletic Director Shawn McCallister

post_text: Steel Valley High School’s Teacher of Gifted Education, Mr. Shawn McCallister, took a group of high school students to CMU’s Entertainment Technology Center on February 18. The students spent a few hours touring the facility with Mr. John Balash. In addition to being a CMU educator and designer and holding a masters degree in Entertainment Technology, Mr. Balash has been a presenter at Walt Disney Imagineer Ideation Summit and was also a finalist in the National Lego Master Builder Search. The students had the opportunity to “play” with some of the creations and got the chance to see some current CMU teams working collaboratively on various projects. One of their favorites was the virtual reality room. This was a great experience for the students and an opportunity for them to learn more about various careers and to simply expand their horizons.
